headline: Vanilla, Cinnamon, and Lime Panna Cotta Recipe
description: This recipe comes straight from one of my favorite places to eat in Chicago, Birrieria Zaragoza. All they serve is birria, a Mexican goat stew served with fresh thick tortillas, and it's impeccable, moan-worthy. But on my last pilgrimage, chef Jonathan Zaragoza offered me this dessert, the best panna cotta I've ever eaten.
name: Vanilla, Cinnamon, and Lime Panna Cotta Recipe
keywords: cinnamon, desserts, puddings, Spice Hunting, vanilla, vanilla beans
recipeIngredient: 1 vanilla bean (either Mexican or Tahitian), split and scraped
Slivered almonds, toasted, for garnish if desired

recipeInstructions.text: In a small bowl, combine half cup of milk with gelatin. Stir to combine and let sit while heating remaining milk, cream, sugar, and salt to a simmer. Add vanilla, cinnamon, and lime zest, and cook at a bare simmer for 10 to 12 minutes.

Remove from heat and stir in milk-gelatin mixture until fully combined. Pour through a fine-mesh strainer into 8 or 6 6- or 8-ounce (respectively) ramekins. Chill for two to three hours, or until set.

To serve, run a thin knife along sides of ramekins to loosen panna cotta. Flip ramekin upside down onto serving plate and tap several times until panna cotta is dislodged. Garnish, if desired, with toasted slivered almonds. This Recipe Appears In 
 Spice Hunting: Sussing Out Vanilla Beans

review.reviewBody: Im going to try this recipe tonight but instead on cinnamon, im going to take a more spring approach and put a strawberries at the bottom.

Rice milk is an interesting idea to give it a more horchata flavor (it has echoes of the drink, but doesn't really taste like it), but keep in mind that it will set into a much firmer gel. One of the reasons I love this recipe so much is how soft and creamy all the cream makes it. Instead, I'd recommend simmering half a cup of rice in about twice the dairy you see here (keeping the proportions intact), then straining and measuring out 3 1/2 cups of that mixture to proceed with the recipe as written. Note I haven't tried this out, but it should give you some of the rice flavor without sacrificing texture. Nossi: I'd just try using more vanilla beans next time. I haven't made vanilla extract before, but there shouldn't be a downside to using more pods. You could try making the extract with some rum as well as vodka, but that may limit the flexibility of the extract somewhat.

I imagine not terribly--there's no rice. You could try using rice milk to replace a large portion of the cow's milk, and get more of that horchata flavor. And that sounds delicious, anyway. I might give it a try!
This got me thinking about the possibilities of a horchata flavoured panna cotta. Did this taste at all like horchata?
